This inscription is strikingly similar to CIJ 774, also from Apamea. The name of the wife is the same, the formulation of the epitaph is the same, and it ends with a warning. However, while in CIJ 774 it ends with the mention of “the Jews” ([τ]ῶν Εἰυοδέων); here it ends with a fine to be paid to the treasury (ταμεῖον). The similarity may suggest a communal affinity, but not necessarily Jewishness.

This inscription has recently been reconstructed as “Deo M[agno] Aeter[no synago]gam pr[oseucham a solo] Claudia P[ia filio] que pecun[ia sua] fecit ex v[oto]” (For the synagogue and prayer house of the great and eternal God, Claudia daughter of Pia made this from her own property, on account of a vow), which means it is a synagogue inscription. However, the reconstruction is very tentative and although both “synagogue” and “proseuche” are terms used for the synagogue, they are never recorded together and have separate geographical provenance, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.1. IJO 2 rejected its Jewishness, see p. 463, n. 28.

It is assumed that her adoptive mother – Aurelia Soteria – is the same as the woman by this name mentioned in CIJ642 as “matri pientissimae religioni Iudeicae metuenti” (very devout mother, a fearer of the Jewish religion) but this description makes Aurelia Soteria not completely Jewish and certainly it need not refer to her possible foster daughter, see Introduction 6.1.6.1. The inscription includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), but see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
See above, n. 2.
In Greek – ἀρχισυνάγωγος.

The declension attached to this name is clearly feminine Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.

The amulet includes many Jewish characteristics such as “in the name of Moses (εἰς̓νόματι Μϋσ )” but this is not an indication that it is Jewish, or that the client (Rufina), for whom it was written, was Jewish, see Introduction 6.9.1.
The suffix is influenced by Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.2. The h here functions as the Greek η, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.2.

The editors thought the inscription Jewish because it mentions Τραιανησίων, and it was assumed, on comparison with the title “Augustinians” found in Jewish inscriptions, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.1, that this was a Jewish community in Porto, which received its civic privileges from the emperor Trajan, but there is no other evidence for this premise. Also, the inscription is dedicated to θεοῦ μεγάλου Διωνύσου (of the Great God Dionysus), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
See above, n. 10.

Strubbe, “Curses,” 98-9, suggests the inscription may be Jewish based on its similarity to JIWE 2, 360, which was found in a Jewish cemetery in Rome, but that inscription was identified as Jewish because of its provenance, see Introduction 6.5.3, and not based on contents, which could be universal Graeco-Roman, and this inscription’s provenance is very different.
The inscription comes from a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.

Appears in a list of names from the catacomb reported by the excavator. The inscription itself was never seen. However, it should be noted that the Monteverde catacomb has been effectively destroyed, so that the veracity of this report cannot be checked.
In Latin – qui vixit annos IV et dies XX (=4 years and 20 days).

W. M. Ramsay, Cities and Bishoprics of Phrygia2 (Oxford 1897) 386-8, considered her husband a convert to Judaism, under Reuben (8)’s influence, see Introduction 6.1.6.2. Robert thought he was a Christian who had converted Reuben the Jew.
On this declension see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.

Jewishness suggested based on two factors: 1. Reference to Θεῷ ̔Υψίστῳ (the God most high) though this is inconclusive, see Introduction 6.10.1.1; and 2. The presence of a clearly Jewish inscription with the same reference from the same location, but see Introduction 6.5.9.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The declension attached to this name is clearly feminine Greek, see Introduction 2.4.2.2.1.

See above, n. 2.

This inscription is strikingly similar to CIJ 774, also from Apamea. The name of the wife is the same. The formulation of the epitaph is the same and it ends with a warning. However, while in CIJ 774 it ends with the mention of [τ]ῶν Εἰυοδέων (the Jews), here it ends with a fine to be paid to the treasury (ταμεῖον). The similarity may suggest a communal affinity, but not necessarily Jewishness.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

Jewishness was suggested by the formula ̓Εά[ν] τις ἀνύξῃ τὸν τάφον δώσει τῇ ἁγιωτά [τῃ] συναγω[γη͂] ἀρ(γύρου) λ(ίτραν μίαν ) (If anyone opens the tomb, he will pay to the most holy synagogue [one] pound silver). However, this inscription comes from Greece, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.4.
In Greek – μ’.

Jewishness suggested based on other name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.
The editor dated the inscription to the “Kaiserzeit.”
See Introduction 2.1. On undeclined forms like this one see Introduction 2.4.4.1.

Robert suggested that the two Greek letters Ιο before her name indicate ̓Ιουδαιῳ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3 but this is very speculative. IJO 2 did not include it in its corpus, see p. 325, n. 48.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.

Jewishness suggested by editor based on other name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.1. In Hierapolis Jewish graves are specifically marked as such, see Introduction 6.1.1.3, and this one is not. IJO 2, considered it not Jewish and did not include it in its corpus, see p. 399, n. 161.
In Latin – βιξιτ αννεις κβ’.

Although the inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3, the stone was reused as a sealing block for a tomb. It also includes the pagan formula D(is Manibus) (to the gods of the underworld), but see Introduction 6.10.2.1.

This amulet mentions the Jewish God by name (Ιαω), but see Introduction 6.10.1.6. Further on the Jewishness of this amulet see Alexander, “Jewish Elements,” 1074-5.
